element.name: The Forty Foot by lenik1, Multi-cache (2/1.5)
element.description: This multicache (all stages and the final cache) is located in Sandycove, near the James Joyce Museum (Martello tower). It is probably best to attempt finding this cache walking. There are several transport links to the cache. It can be reached from the Sandycove DART station and the 7, 46A and 75 busses (bus stop in Dun Laoghaire). Or you can park your car at N 53° 17.430 W 006° 07.620.

long-description.p: The Forty Foot is a promontory on the southern tip of Dublin Bay at Dún Laoghaire where people have swum in the Irish Sea all year round for some 250 years. It is famous for offering a swimming point to those who are brave enough to face the chilling temperature of the Irish Sea.

In former times it was kept solely as a gentlemen's bathing place and the gentlemen's swimming club was established to help conserve the area. Things have changed since then, and the place is now also open to women and children as well. The gentlemen's swimming club still exists and is open to both genders.

The area may have been called the Forty Foot after the 42nd Highland Regiment of Foot (now known as the Black Watch), a regiment of the British Army, which built a fortress here in 1747. Another theory is that it took its name from the nearest train stop in the 1800s, which was at Dun Laoghaire (then Kingstown). Just outside the station, the road leading up to the town was 40ft wide. Passengers from Dublin coming for a swim said they were alighting at the "forty foot" and over time the name transferred itself to the swimming spot, which back then was about 20 feet to the left of where most swimmers now enter the water.

The Martello Tower is located just a few tens of meters from The Forty Foot and James Joyce, a writer of international renown, resided there. The tower now holds a museum (James Joyce Museum), devoted to the life and works of him. He used the tower setting for the first chapter of his masterpiece, Ulysses.
To find the cache you will need to visit a couple of locations first.
Stage One: N 53° 17.249 W 006° 06.999. At this stage, you will see a commemorative stone. Take a date when the tree was planted in May 1983 and call it AB.
Stage Two: N 53° 17.321 W 006° 06.861. At this location, you will see a few lifebuoys. How many lifebuoys are there? Call this C.
Stage Three: N 53° 17.366 W 006° 06.831. At this stage, there is a few low colored corner stones (not the lithic blockstones!!!). How many of these stones are there? Call this D.
Stage Four: N 53° 17.321 W 006° 06.811. At this location, you will see some stairs. How many stairs are leading to the tower? Call this E.

You now have everything you need to find the cache. Don´t forget what you have to COUNT FIRST during the counting. Just bethink of Maths at primary school and you get it. The cache can be found at:
N53° 17. (31 x B - D)
W006° 06. [3 x C] [(A x B) – (2 x D)] [3 x E + A]

The cache is a small tupperware container with a logbook, a pen, a sharpener and some stuff for trade. Please take out a cache with extreme care because it’s muggled area, especially at sunny days. Replace the cache carefully and EXACTLY as you found it!

element.additional-waypoints:
FF1QHJT - The Forty Foot
N 53° 17.366 W 006° 06.831
MT1QHJT - Martello Tower
N 53° 17.321 W 006° 06.811
SB1QHJT - Sandycove Beach
N 53° 17.321 W 006° 06.861
element.encoded-hints: clear sight helps you, 2m above ground

ul.li:
2010-05-11T19:00:00Z : Found it by pajavanka
Holliday in IRL. Found it with hellynka. Thx leni :)

2010-05-11T19:00:00Z : Found it by Hellynka
TFTC Leni, sice nám na to pršelo, ale asi to bylo štestí :)

2010-03-17T19:00:00Z : Found it by Blue Jay 59
Had done all the stages done a couple of weeks ago, but were a bit confused about the corner stones etc. After an email to the owner, she very kindly emailed help with our maths & the stones [:D]
So just got back out to the 40 Foot to find this little one today. It was lovely out there on a mild and warm St.Patricks day. Didn't see any coin. TFTC & the puzzle. Blue Jay 59 #251

2010-03-17T19:00:00Z : Found it by Toffee Man
A nice multi cache. We had the stages worked out & found the cache today TFTC Toffee Man #251
[This entry was edited by Toffee Man on Wednesday, March 17, 2010 at 2:02:10 PM.]

2010-02-14T20:00:00Z : Found it by msi999
It wasn't easy to understand what means "few low colored corner stones", but with two versions of final coordinates we get it. TFTC! ;)

wpt.name: GC1QHJT
wpt.desc: The Forty Foot by lenik1, Multi-cache (2/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: The Forty Foot
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This multicache (all stages and the final cache) is located in Sandycove, near the James Joyce Museum (Martello tower). It is probably best to attempt finding this cache walking. There are several transport links to the cache. It can be reached from the Sandycove DART station and the 7, 46A and 75 busses (bus stop in Dun Laoghaire). Or you can park your car at N 53° 17.430 W 006° 07.620.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
THE FORTY FOOT

The Forty Foot is a promontory on the southern tip of Dublin Bay at Dún Laoghaire where people have swum in the Irish Sea all year round for some 250 years. It is famous for offering a swimming point to those who are brave enough to face the chilling temperature of the Irish Sea.

In former times it was kept solely as a gentlemen's bathing place and the gentlemen's swimming club was established to help conserve the area. Things have changed since then, and the place is now also open to women and children as well. The gentlemen's swimming club still exists and is open to both genders.

The area may have been called the Forty Foot after the 42nd Highland Regiment of Foot (now known as the Black Watch), a regiment of the British Army, which built a fortress here in 1747. Another theory is that it took its name from the nearest train stop in the 1800s, which was at Dun Laoghaire (then Kingstown). Just outside the station, the road leading up to the town was 40ft wide. Passengers from Dublin coming for a swim said they were alighting at the "forty foot" and over time the name transferred itself to the swimming spot, which back then was about 20 feet to the left of where most swimmers now enter the water.

The Martello Tower is located just a few tens of meters from The Forty Foot and James Joyce, a writer of international renown, resided there. The tower now holds a museum (James Joyce Museum), devoted to the life and works of him. He used the tower setting for the first chapter of his masterpiece, Ulysses.

The Cache:

To find the cache you will need to visit a couple of locations first.

Stage One: N 53° 17.249 W 006° 06.999. At this stage, you will see a commemorative stone. Take a date when the tree was planted in May 1983 and call it AB.

Stage Two: N 53° 17.321 W 006° 06.861. At this location, you will see a few lifebuoys. How many lifebuoys are there? Call this C.

Stage Three: N 53° 17.366 W 006° 06.831. At this stage, there is a few low colored corner stones (not the lithic blockstones!!!). How many of these stones are there? Call this D.

Stage Four: N 53° 17.321 W 006° 06.811. At this location, you will see some stairs. How many stairs are leading to the tower? Call this E.

You now have everything you need to find the cache. Don´t forget what you have to COUNT FIRST during the counting. Just bethink of Maths at primary school and you get it. The cache can be found at:
N53° 17. (31 x B - D)
 W006° 06. [3 x C] [(A x B) – (2 x D)] [3 x E + A]

The cache is a small tupperware container with a logbook, a pen, a sharpener and some stuff for trade. Please take out a cache with extreme care because it’s muggled area, especially at sunny days. Replace the cache carefully and EXACTLY as you found it!

Additional Waypoints

FF1QHJT - The Forty Foot
N 53° 17.366 W 006° 06.831

MT1QHJT - Martello Tower
N 53° 17.321 W 006° 06.811

SB1QHJT - Sandycove Beach
N 53° 17.321 W 006° 06.861
